DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airline Reduces Schedule
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines announced its first cut in scheduled daily flights since it began its reorganization last March at the outset of a long strike, and said it might lay off some employees. The carrier, which earlier in the week sold its Latin American routes to American Airlines, announced Friday it was cutting daily flights from 830 to 802 effective Jan. 31. Eliminated flights include some nonstop service from Miami to Boston, Philadelphia, Orlando, Tampa, and runs to several Caribbean cities. More flight cutbacks are to follow once the deal with American has been completed. Eastern told employees this week that ``some furloughs may be necessary as we reduce operations.'' But the airline doesn't anticipate ayoffs of pilots, flight attendants or mechanics, Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said Friday. Eastern, which had more than 30,000 employees and 1,040 daily flights before the strike began March 4, now employs about 20,000 workers, most of them non-union. The flight reduction was prompted by economic priorities, Matell said. ``We're trying to develop the best possible schedule that opens the most potential for profitability,'' he said. Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors five days after its three unions struck last March. In April, the carrier announced plans to rebuild to about two-thirds its pre-strike size. In August, negotiations over the sale of Eastern's Central and South American routes to American stalled, and Eastern officials said they would keep those routes and build back to 90 percent of their airline's pre-strike size. But Eastern creditors reportedly were displeased over projected cash shortfalls, prompting the sale this week of the Latin American service and other assets by Eastern's parent, Texas Air Corp. Approval of the sale to American by the U.S. Department of Transportation and the U.S. bankruptcy court is expected to take up to six months, and Eastern will continue to fly the routes until approval has been granted. Officials of the Machinists union, the only union still on strike, said Eastern's planes are flying at less than half capacity in spite of the airline's sharp discounting to boost business. Eastern flights averaged about 50 percent occupancy during the first half of December, Matell said.
